awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Impacts of Increased Light Transmittance on Ocean Heating, Primary Productivity, and Carbon Cycling Across a Pacific Arctic Continental Shelf Gradient
awd_abstract_narration:
Arctic sea ice is undergoing tremendous changes. There has been a pronounced decrease in summer sea ice cover, an overall thinning of the ice, and a lengthening of the summer melt season. Some of the greatest changes in sea ice cover across the pan-Arctic have been observed in the Chukchi and Beaufort Seas surrounding Alaska, where there has been substantial loss of perennial sea ice that persists year-round (including during summer). This Pacific Arctic sector is also among the most biologically productive marine ecosystems in the world and is an important region to monitor for the flow of carbon. Although sea ice is a dominant feature in these shallow marine environments at high-latitudes, we are only beginning to understand how changes in sea ice cover (through its influence on light, seawater temperature, salinity, and nutrient availability) will affect ecosystems in these regions. In particular, earlier ice-free conditions in the spring (as well as later ice-free conditions in the fall) have disrupted the timing of algae blooms and the livelihoods of marine mammals farther up the food chain. This research is focusing upon measurements of light transmittance through the ocean water column collected at science stations during the Synoptic Arctic Survey (SAS) cruise on the US Coast Guard Ship Healy. Measurements of light transmittance through the water column will further our understanding of how light impacts heat distribution, algae growth, and carbon flows throughout the region. In addition, this project is supporting an early-career researcher and the team is contributing material for numerous undergraduate courses and partnering with the Girls Inc. organization to involve middle and high school students in opportunities to learn about Arctic Ocean science.

This research is establishing new measurements of light transmittance (320–780 nm) through the uppermost ~30–50 m of the ocean water column at observation points across a continental shelf gradient (over the Chukchi Shelf into the deep Arctic Ocean basin, with the return southward over the Chukchi Borderlands). These measurements are providing the baseline knowledge necessary to understand how light availability in the water column changes spatially (across a ~2000 km long continental shelf/latitudinal gradient) as well as temporally (across a seasonal gradient from early September through late October). Using these measurements, the team is testing the hypothesis that light transmittance increases with declines in sea ice cover and varies with light absorbing impurities in the water column. The seasonal timing and geographic location of the SAS cruise provide a rare opportunity to further assess the connections of late-open-water-season light transmittance to all three research focal areas of the SAS science and implementation plan: (1) physical drivers, (2) ecosystem responses, and (3) carbon cycling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Declines in sea ice cover across the Arctic owing to climate warming have substantial consequences for increased light transmittance through the water column, which in turn has critical consequences for: (a) vertical heat distribution (and potential contributions back to sea ice melt), (b) available light for primary productivity, and (c) the photodegradation of dissolved organic matter through ultraviolet (UV) and visible light exposure. This project added new optical measurements of light transmittance through the upper ocean water column across a continental shelf gradient to an existing suite of observations on the Synoptic Arctic Survey US cruise to the central Arctic Ocean in September and October 2022. The seasonal timing and geographic location of the US SAS cruise provided a rare opportunity to further assess the connections of late-open-water-season light transmittance to all three research focal areas of the SAS science and implementation plan: (1) physical drivers, (2) ecosystem responses, and (3) carbon cycling.

Optical casts were collected by an early career researcher aboard the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Healy September–October 2022 to the North Pole. Light transmittance was collected using a Biospherical Compact-Optical Profiling System (C-OPS) that collects both downwelling irradiance and upwelling radiance at 19 channels (320, 340, 380, 395, 412, 443, 465, 490, 510, 532, 555, 560, 625, 665, 670, 683, 710, 780 nm), and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR, 400–700 nm) and upwelling phytoplankton fluorescence. The C-OPS was manually deployed from the surface ocean to ~50 m depth, collecting light in cm-scale vertical resolution. Processing steps included removing inconsistencies in depth progression owing to swells, analyzing up- and downcasts individually per station, filtering out poor quality data based on tilt of the instrument, removing data values exceeding the instrument’s detection limits, and normalizing transmittance based on surface irradiance collected simultaneously to the below-sea surface measurements. The transmittance was smoothed using a LOWESS procedure through depth and uploaded to the Arctic Data Center repository for public distribution.

We tested the hypothesis that light transmittance varies with light absorbing impurities, specifically chlorophyll-a pigments, in the water column. The sampled phytoplankton blooms were found to absorb irradiance and increase heating rates at the vertical location of subsurface blooms while shading deeper depths from irradiance. In fact, the optical profiles collected in the Pacific Arctic region during the fall season associated each 1 μg/L increase of chlorophyll-a at the chlorophyll-a maximum with an approximate 12% decrease in heating rate within the 10 meters below the chlorophyll-a maximum depth. The finding that phytoplankton blooms trapped heat could affect stratification and potentially hinder sea ice formation depending on where blooms occur within the water column. This observation raises questions regarding how much heat is added in the upper water column during fall phytoplankton bloom events, and if it is enough to delay sea ice formation as a potential feedback. The questions addressed provide a synergistic understanding of how the Arctic marine system is responding to ongoing climate warming and sea ice decline in the fall months.

Results of this project were disseminated to diverse audiences in several formats. Findings were presented at the International Synoptic Arctic Survey Synthesis Workshop, American Geophysical Union, Ocean Sciences Meeting, the Alaska Marine Science Symposium, and the Synoptic Arctic Survey webinar series. Results were presented in several undergraduate and graduate courses Clark University and the College of the Holy Cross. Outreach activities to K-12 students included curriculum development and visits to Girls Inc. of Worcester, which is a 106-year-old organization in Worcester, Massachusetts with a purpose to give ethical, educational, and social advantages to girls of lower income families. In particular, the “Eureka!” program at Girls Inc. is a flagship, five-year STEM program that seeks to engage girls in grades 8–12 (ages 13–18) in STEM-intensive programming.
